If we get gay marriage in this country, it will not come from Congress, it will come from the courts. I am a lawyer and took constitutional law in the 1970s from Charles Alan Wright, a well known scholar on federal courts and constitutional law. At the time we discussed the law of equal protection and the high standard that was required for the states to support legislation that discriminated based on race, so called "suspect classifications". Professor Wright said that homosexuality was also a suspect classification like race. In effect,that means that it is virtually impossible for the government to defend efforts to discrimininate based on homosexuality.

While the right wing extremists on the Supreme Court (Scalia, Thomas, and Alito) would doubtless ignore the law and come up with some disingenous theory to ignore legal precedent and deny gay people who want to marry their constitutional rights, hopefully the rest of the the Court will strike down laws that prevent gay people from marrying. All that could change if the Republicans sweep the 2012 elections and get to put more bigoted zealots on the court.

If we really were a secular society, there would be no controversy about same sex marriage. Religious points of view are forced upon others . There is freedom of religion and there is also freedom from religion. As a Catholic, I am disappointed by my own church's intolerance. But, what can one expect from a church that took 500 years to apologize to Galileo. I am anxious to see if the Supreme Court will address this marriage equality issue. If the justices put aside any personal prejudices, at what other rational decision could they arrive ?

So, the public may not support it, it may be alien to the cultural heritage of a country, it may not have social backing--but what is all of that when the elite decide that JUSTICE or EQUAL PROTECTION or whatever other hackneyed "solution" they can invoke allows them to amass the leviathan power of the state to say that something is what it isn't.  So, the government has decided marriage has no relation to sex.  What clear-thinking person would say a government can legislate that, geometric rules notwithstanding, the number of sides of a polygon is irrelevant to what the polygon is...and we cannot allow three-sided shapes to be "discriminated" against because they can't enjoy the rights and privileges (and angles) of a square.  No, no amount of government decree can make ersatz marriage into marriage, though the far more dangerous phenomenon is governments that think they can.  In that, Mr. Soares (and his Spanish counterpart) may have more in common with the "we have the power we can do what we want" dictatorships they profess to abhor and from which they at least claim they are distancing themselves.  Benedict XVI got it right when he described it in 2005 as the "dictatorship of relativism," a dictatorship which nevertheless demands absolute fidelity (just ask certain town clerks in New York State).

The majority of Americans don't live in SF or NYC and have a different view.  What is the upside for Obama?  Support gay marriage and end up like Jimmy Carter. If you are gay, it is likely that gay marriage makes you a single issue voter.  But they have no where to go except Obama.  Obama does not move on this issue.

Cheers, Joe Mustich, CT USA, Justice of the Peace.

I believe the best analogy is a criminal in your house with a gun. What will you do? Will you restrain him to ensure he has a due process of law? Or do you shoot him without hesitation because he's already made his decisions and forced your hand to protect other innocents? I would shoot him without hesitation. And I don't think the Constitution would have any problem with that. It is understood that citizens have the right to defend themselves even from other citizens. The same applies to police and other law agencies. This man was beyond practical reach and we had an opportunity to remove a threat to our nation. If you think we should have put boos on the ground and captured him how about you go try that? When you get killed trying I'll tell you I told you so. He chose his side. We don't have to wait for him to formally renounce his citizenship to kill him. And I like the idea of basically having a trial without him present and finding him guilty...the problem is that we can't have normal citizens deciding foreign policy like that. What would we have done if a court found him innocent? Leave him be until he killed innocents? Our laws don't cover every edge case like this. Using a little common sense I feel safe in saying ovur founding fathers would applaud the decision to remove this threat to our nation. Laws don't apply universally in every case. If you have a guy dying in your car right now are you going to abide by the traffic and speed laws? No. You're going to rush him to the hospital because it is more important to do that than to boy the speed limit. I think this is a similar situation where the standard law doesn't cover a case but we can use some common sense to find a proper solution.
